title: cmscan,cmsearch cpu & mpi option definitions
body:
@nawrockie 

Hi Eric ,

I was going though cmsearch and cmscan code and noticed that you have the constants `CPUOPTS` and `MPIOPTS` that define `--cpu` and `--mpi` options reversed (cmscan lines: **110-113** and cmsearch lines: **84-87**).  

For convenience I'm copying lines **110-113** from **cmscan** below:

``` c
#if defined (HMMER_THREADS) && defined (HAVE_MPI)
#define CPUOPTS     "--mpi"
#define MPIOPTS     "--cpu"
#else
```

They are both only used once under `#ifdef HMMER_THREADS` and `#ifdef HAVE_MPI`, lines **170** and **174** respectively. 

I was wondering if these would be troublesome when compiling the code with the `--enable-mpi` option, or whether there's a reason why they are set this way. 

Kind regards,
Ioanna

title: Inconsistent results from qsort callback
body:
Hi,

`qsort` callback `hit_sorter_by_evalue` may return random result when input structs have all compared fields equal. This in turn may causes inconsistent order or even [crashes](https://bugzilla.samba.org/show_bug.cgi?id=3959) in some qsort implementations.

The issue has been detected when running standard testsuite under [SortChecker](https://github.com/yugr/sortcheck):
```
cmsearch[23540]: qsort: comparison function is not symmetric (comparison function 0x4ab689 (/home/yugr/build/infernal-1.1.1/src/cmsearch+0x4ab689), called from 0x4abb66 (/home/yugr/build/infernal-1.1.1/src/cmsearch+0x4abb66), cmdline is "../src/cmsearch -E 0.1 --tblout esltmpaa22822.OUTFILES.tbl esltmpaa22822.OUTFILES.cm esltmpaa22822.OUTFILES.fa")
```

Closer examination in debugger reveals that `hit_sorter_by_evalue` returns returns the same value for equal results:
```
(gdb) p hit_sorter_by_evalue(&h->hit[2], &h->hit[3])
$15 = -1
(gdb) p hit_sorter_by_evalue(&h->hit[3], &h->hit[2])
$16 = -1
```
The fix is simply to replace final comparison
```
return  (h1->pass_idx < h2->pass_idx ? 1 : -1 ); /* fourth key, pass_idx, high to low */
```
with
```
return  (h1->pass_idx < h2->pass_idx ? 1 : h1->pass_idx > h2->pass_idx ? -1 : 0); /* fourth key, pass_idx, high to low */
```

A similar issue seems to exist in most other `hit_sorter*` callbacks .

title: annotating a large assembly/scaffolds
body:
Hello,
What is the best way to annotate a large genome assembly? 
My assembly is 4.5 Gb in total, with a scaffold N50 of 3 Mb (80% of the sequence is in scf >1 Mb). 
After reading here http://rfam.readthedocs.io/en/latest/genome-annotation.html, I thought of splitting the assembly in 20 chunks, but still I would need almost 500 GB of RAM.
Besides splitting in smaller files, is there a way to run it efficiently (also, controlling the number of cpus that it takes on a local server)?
With smaller genomes, my command is 
`cmscan -Z 59.752452 --cut_ga --rfam --nohmmonly --tblout genome12_infernal --fmt 1 --clanin Rfam12.2.claninfo Rfam.desc.cm genome12.fasta > genome12.cmscan`
thanks,

Dario

title: Identifying group II introns in gymnosperm mitochondria
body:
I'm using Infernal and RFAM to identify group II introns in gymnosperm mitochondria. Using `cmscan --mid --cut_ga --nohmmonly` it identifies 8 out of 16 family Intron_gpII ([RF00029](http://rfam.org/family/RF00029)). Using the Infernal CM for Domain-V ([RM00007](http://rfam.xfam.org/motif/RM00007)) it's able to identify all 16 introns, which is great! Could an RFAM family be constructed from this motif?

I see that no gymnosperm mitochondria are present in sequences of RF00029, which may be the cause of the lack of sensitivity that I observed. Could the mitochondrial genomes of *Cycas taitungensis* NC_010303.1, *Ginkgo biloba* NC_027976.1, *Welwitschia mirabilis* NC_029130.1, and *Picea glauca* LKAM01.1 be added to the Intron_gpII (RF00029) family?

I found no hits at all to clan group-II-D1D4 ([CL00102](http://rfam.xfam.org/clan/CL00102)) in my gymnosperm mitochondrial genomes. Could a new family be added to this clan constructed from plant mitochondrial genomes, including gymnsoperms?

Thank you for Infernal and RFAM! When cmscan is able to find a match to Intron_gpII, it is often is able to identify the exact 3' splice site of the intron, which is not always straight forward by eye.

- downloaded ftp://ftp.ebi.ac.uk/pub/databases/Rfam/12.1/Rfam.cm.gz

Followed instructions as described on p27 of http://eddylab.org/infernal/Userguide.pdf and cmscan fails with error:
FAIL: Error: unable to find model RyeB listed in Rfam.12.1.clanin in SSI index file

I just deleted RyeB from the Rfam.12.1.clanin file and it appears to run.

title: Report: cmalign --small options error message is truncated ?
body:
Hello,

When using cmalign with option --small, it looks like several other options are mandatory.
But the error message is truncated:

> Failed to parse command line: Option --small requires (or has no effect without) option(s) --cyk,--noprob,--nonband
> Usage: cmalign [-options] <cmfile> <seqfile>
> 
> where basic options are:
>   -h     : show brief help on version and usage
>   -o <f> : output the alignment to file <f>, not stdout
>   -g     : configure CM for global alignment [default: local]
> 
> To see more help on available options, do cmalign -h

It seems that in addition to the three options mentionned, we need to use --notrunc to correctly launch cmalign. I wish the error message was complete: _Option --small requires (or has no effect without) option(s) --cyk,--noprob,--nonbanded **and --notrunc**_

Steps to reproduce:

- launch cmalign with options --small, --cyk, --noprob and --nonband: `cmalign --small --cyk --noprob --nonband yourfile.cm yourfile.fa`

This was just a small report.
Thank you,

Louis

title: RF annotation can impact model building even when --hand is not used
body: Due to how esl_msaweight_PB{_adv}() is implemented, RF annotation can impact MSA weighting if the provided RF annotation is not identical to what esl_msaweight_PB_adv()'s method for determining RF (match/insert) would determine. This means the same input alignment to cmbuild with and without RF annotation can result in different models. RF should be ignored unless --hand is used. Fix is: (EddyRivasLab/infernal@fba203f)

title: time complexity of cmsearch
body:
I wonder how to calculate the complexity of cmsearch. I originally thought that to search a query covariance model with L1 positions through a database of M sequences, with average length of L2, the time complexity should be around O(L1*M*L2). However, this does not seem to be the case. In the attached example, the query covariance model has 307 positions, and the sequence database is only 32M. cmsearch (INFERNAL 1.1.3, 64 bit Linux) has been running for more than 2 days, but has not yet finished:

```bash
cmsearch --noali -A cmsearch.a2m --cpu 2 seq.cm seq.db
```

[input.zip](https://github.com/EddyRivasLab/infernal/files/5939417/input.zip)

```
Windows   passing glocal HMM Forward  bias filter:               4  (0.5); expected (0.02)
Envelopes passing glocal HMM envelope defn filter:               4  (0.5); expected (0.02)
Envelopes passing  local CM  CYK           filter:               4  (0.5); expected (0.0001)
Total CM hits reported:                                          1  (0.1608); includes 1 truncated hit(s)

# CPU time: 5.14u 0.12s 00:00:05.26 Elapsed: 00:00:05.26
//
[ok]
```

My parser expects every alignment block to have the `PP` line, which is missing here. Is that a bug or are there any good reasons why this line is missing?

Switching to global alignments `-g` produces the `PP` line, as well as `--notrunc` or a combination of both flags.

title: Bug allows truncated hits to start/end internally
body:
The default search/scan pipeline is supposed to enforce that truncated hits include the first/final nucleotide in a sequence (`5'` and `5'&3'` truncated hits must contain nucleotide `1`, and `3'` and `5'&3'` truncated hits must contain nucleotide `L` for a sequence of length `L`).

There's a bug in the pipeline code that prevents this enforcement in rare cases, such that a `5'` truncated hit starts after nucleotide `1` and a `3'` truncated hit ends before nucleotide `L`. I've only seen this with big models (LSU) when a fragment of an LSU sequence exists in the middle of a sequence, presumably due to a misassembly, although certain biologically correct introns might allow this to happen also.

Three example sequences that exhibit this are listed below, using the Rfam 14.1 LSU bacterial model (RF02541), and the command: `cmsearch --rfam --cpu 0 --nohmmonly --cut_ga RF02541.cm in.fa`.

* `QYUU01000014.1, L=1370`: `5'` truncated hit on `+` strand starts at position `2 != 1`

* `PRGG01000010.1, L=1975`: `3'` truncated hit on `+` strand ends at position `1955 != 1975`

* `BMWJ01000078.1, L=804`: `5'&3'` truncated hit on `+` strand starts at position `616 != 1`

I will log/test this with these examples in the testsuite and am working on a fix now.

title: cmbuild with fragmentary sequences, terminal self-inserts can lead to problematically high self-insert probabilities
body: For `cmbuild` to more appropriately handle missing data from fragmentary sequences (being implemented in the `buildfrags` feature branch), truncated parsetrees are allowed, but in rare cases if a parsetree ends with self inserts (IL->IL or IR->IR) it may lead to the corresponding self-insert probability that is problematically high. If the only transitions for an insert state implied by the alignment are self inserts, then all other transition counts will be 0, and the self insert can be very close to 1.0. This can be a problem in the QDB calculation engine, which is a step performed by `cmbuild` to determine the model's `W` parameter. If `W` grows larger than 1000 times the model length (`clen`) `cmbuild` fails with an error as this was thought to be an indication that something was wrong. This is undesirable for the impact on W and the expected length distribution from the offending insert, so instead of increasing the `1000*clen` threshold, I want to modify the parsetree somehow to avoid such a high self-insert probability in these cases.

title: cmalign core dump
body:
Dear infernal team. I try to build new CM for mitochondrial 16S. The following command line gives me a core dump:

```
cmalign --verbose -g --notrunc --cpu 0 --mxsize 65536 --sfile rrnL-bact.score -o rrnL-bact-org.stk --mapali LSU_rRNA_bacteria-RF02541.clean.stk LSU_rRNA_bacteria-RF02541.clean.cm rrnLtmp.fas
```

I tried with (`--cpu 8, 16, 32`) and without mutithreading (`--cpu 0`), played around with various `-mxsize` settings and I'm also pretty sure that the problem is not a lack of RAM (I have >1TB available and `cmalign` seemed to be quite a bit away from this .. depending on the number of cores I have seen up to ~300GB in the htop output). I'm using the 1.1.4 bioconda package, but also tried a local build.

I deposited the input data over here https://nc.ufz.de/s/tWsyE7dZg58LBaB  (password is `:v;{I8Ozl1`)

Would be grateful for any suggestions or help of any sort.

title: Bug: cmbuild --noh3pri results in use of v0.56->v1.0.2 prior instead of default prior
body: Looks like this was just a coding mistake, grouping --noh3pri with the other --p56 and --v1p0 prior-related options. Should be a simple fix.

title: column offset in `--tblout`?
body:
I found an offset in the starting positions of columns when using `cmsearch` with the [14.9 Rfam collection](https://ftp.ebi.ac.uk/pub/databases/Rfam/14.9/Rfam.cm.gz) against the [UCSC derived hg19 assembly](https://hgdownload.soe.ucsc.edu/goldenPath/hg19/bigZips/hg19.fa.gz).
```
#target name         accession query name           accession mdl mdl from   mdl to  seq from    seq to strand trunc pass   gc  bias  score   E-value inc description of target
#------------------- --------- -------------------- --------- --- -------- -------- --------- --------- ------ ----- ---- ---- ----- ------ --------- --- ---------------------
chr1                 -         5S_rRNA              RF00001    cm        1      119 228746133 228746015      -    no    1 0.61   0.0  118.9   6.6e-24 !   -
chr1                 -         5S_rRNA              RF00001    cm        1      119 228748374 228748256      -    no    1 0.61   0.0  118.9   6.6e-24 !   -
.
.
.
chr2                 -         U1                   RF00003    cm        1      166  56274720  56274797      +    no    1 0.33   0.0   20.2       7.4 ?   -
chr1                 -         U1                   RF00003    cm        1      166 109517705 109517546      -    no    1 0.38   0.0   19.9       9.2 ?   -
chr11                 -         U2                   RF00004    cm        1      193  62609281  62609091      -    no    1 0.44   0.0  191.2   9.7e-40 !   -
chr10                 -         U2                   RF00004    cm        1      193 103124792 103124602      -    no    1 0.45   0.0  179.5   6.2e-37 !   -
.
.
.
chr8                  -         U2                   RF00004    cm        1      193  57741437  57741496      +    no    1 0.28   0.0   24.4       9.9 ?   -
chr15                 -         U2                   RF00004    cm        1      193  54034824  54035003      +    no    1 0.34   0.5   24.4        10 ?   -
chr6                 -         tRNA                 RF00005    cm        1       71  28442402  28442329      -    no    1 0.50   0.0   76.8   2.4e-14 !   -
chr7                 -         tRNA                 RF00005    cm        1       71 149007281 149007352      +    no    1 0.56   0.0   73.9   1.6e-13 !   -
```
If you take a look at the second column `accession` the fields are all `-` but this character seems to jump back and forth from position 22 to 23. This breaks my current parser and I wonder if this is intended or not. The above example is produced with version 1.1.3 on `Linux rs500-bcf-10 5.15.0-78-generic #85~20.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Mon Jul 17 09:42:39 UTC 2023 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
`
I am currently running INFERNAL 1.1.5 (Sep 2023) to see if this issue persists ... yes, it does

title: cmbuild --refine bug related to fragments
body: If the input MSA has fragments with missing data characters at the 5' and/or 3' ends and --refine is used with cmbuild, the program with crash with a segmentation fault.

title: cmpress fails without useful information when .cm file contains 2 models with identical NAME
body:
If a `.cm` file contains multiple models, and some of them have identical `NAME`, `cmpress` will fail as:
```
Working...     %
```
There is no useful information, so it's difficult to address the issue. 

If it could print the model NAME causing the problem, it would be very helpful.

I used version 1.1.4. I have not tried version 1.1.5, but I guess it would be the same, since I see nothing related to `cmpress` in the release note of version 1.1.5
